speaker: Frasier
text: Who's up next, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Cleo from Redmond on line three.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_presses button_] Hello, Cleo.  I'm listening.

speaker: Cleo
text: [_v.o._] Hi, Dr. Crane.  I've been dating three different guys,  and I can't choose between them.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is it that you can't choose, or you don't want to choose?

speaker: Cleo
text: It's just hard.  One's really funny, one's adventurous,  and one's sensitive.  They're all gorgeous too.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, excuse me, Cleo!  This show is for people with real  problems!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz.  Um, it sounds to me as if each suitor possesses one  quality that you admire.  Rather than choose among them,  why not try to find one person who fits all your criteria?

speaker: Roz
text: Why don't you call back when you're a working single mother  whose choice in dates is between a guy with eight teeth and  a guy whose hair is painted on?!

speaker: Frasier
text: Sadly, we're out of time.  This is Dr. Frasier Crane saying  good day, Seattle, and good mental health - unless of course  Roz has a problem with that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is there something wrong, Roz?  Because if there is, we should  discuss it before it bleeds into your work.

speaker: Roz
text: I'm sorry.  I'm just sick of hearing people complain about  their love lives while I face another weekend without plans.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I empathize, but-

speaker: Roz
text: I know, look who I'm telling.

speaker: Frasier
text: It so happens I have big plans this weekend!

speaker: Roz
text: Let me guess.  You and Niles are playing your zithers again at  the Renaissance Fair.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, the Renaissance Fair is a fortnight after St. Swithin's  Day.  No, my son is coming to town.  In fact, Dad and Daphne  should be picking him up at the airport right now.

speaker: Roz
text: I didn't know Freddie was coming!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it was sort of last-minute, actually.  You know, you  remember I had that reunion of sorts with my old college  mentor, Dr. Tewkesbury.  Well, it led to a lot of soul  searching.  He helped me to realize that I've been defining  myself by my career, and it's time that I rearranged my  priorities.  And my first priority is my son.

speaker: Roz
text: What is he now, twelve?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, thirteen, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Wow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, you know, the years really have flown by.  I feel like I've missed so much.

speaker: Roz
text: So what are you guys gonna do?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, lots of things!  I thought we'd go and see a play, and,  uh, maybe take in the computer show - he'd love that - and,  uh, oh, I've decided we are going to read "Walden" together.

speaker: Roz
text: Some vacation.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, Roz, it is, actually.  You see, every year we pick a  book to read and discuss.  It's been sort of a bonding thing  between us.  Gosh, you know, I hate to brag, but Freddie  really is a very articulate young man.  He's very imaginative,  and not to mention what a great sense of humor he has.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, that reminds me, Frasier!  Alice said the cutest thing  this morning-

speaker: Frasier
text: Now careful, Roz, you don't want to turn into one of those  mothers who bores everybody talking about her child.    _He leaves.    FADE OUT    Scene Two - Apartment  Martin is watching the TV.  Frederick is talking on the cordless phone.    Frederick is not as we remember him.  His hair is buzzed short, he has  an earring, and he's taken on the glazed indifference that separates  teenagers from children and adults._

speaker: Freddie
text: At Level Seven, grab the Bio-suit, and then teleport to the  acid tank.  Really?  Hey Grandpa, put on MTV, Channel 46.

speaker: Martin
text: All right.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, jeez!  What is this?  They're half-nude!  It's just not  right!

speaker: Freddie
text: [_into phone_] I saw this one already!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hello, Dad. [_sees Frederick_] Freddie, ha-ha!  Come give  your dad a hug!

speaker: Freddie
text: [_into phone_] I'll call you back.  _As he hangs up, Frasier scoops him up in a bear hug, which Frederick  returns less than enthusiastically._

speaker: Frasier
text: Gosh, it's so good to see you!  Well, so how was your flight?

speaker: Freddie
text: Eh.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good, good, good, good.  Did you get all your unpacking done?

speaker: Freddie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Great!  Gosh, I've been really looking forward to seeing you.  We're gonna have so much fun.  What would you like to do first?

speaker: Freddie
text: Whatever. [_phone rings, he answers_] Hello?  Hey, Zack!  Hang on, let me get some privacy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's certainly not the greeting I was expecting.

speaker: Martin
text: I've never seen such dancing.  What do you think those shorts  are made of?

speaker: Frasier
text: Some sort of... steel mesh.  What the hell are you watching?!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh! [_turns it off_] It's Freddie's program.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good lord.  He doesn't seem very happy to be here.  He hardly  said two words to me.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's perfectly normal.  You're his dad.  Kids that age  don't want to talk to their dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: I never stopped talking to you.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sighs_] I know, buddy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Evening.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hi, Daph.

speaker: Daphne
text: Dinner will be ready soon.  Niles is joining us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good, good.  Say, Daphne, did Freddie say anything in the car?

speaker: Daphne
text: Not really.  We put your show on the radio.  Heard Roz give  that caller the business.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'll get that.  You know, it's a pity she hasn't found  someone to love.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm.

speaker: Daphne
text: I mean, what could be sadder than growing old alone? [_realizes_]  I wasn't talking about you, Dr. Crane.  You've got your father  to grow old with.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles, hi.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello. [_kisses her_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey Niles, I didn't miss a squash date, did I?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh no, no, no.  I was playing with Jack Belcher from the club.  He pummeled me but good!  From now on, I'll stick to playing  you.  Where's Freddie, I can't wait to see him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, oh, I'll go and get him.

speaker: Daphne
text: You always smell so masculine after you've finished exercising.

speaker: Niles
text: [_butch_] It's the mango-kiwi shower gel.    _The doorbell rings again.  Daphne opens it to Jack, a tall man also  dressed in squash togs._

speaker: Jack
text: Hi, there.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, hello.

speaker: Jack
text: I'm Jack, I just dropped Niles off.

speaker: Niles
text: Jack?

speaker: Jack
text: [_hands him a sweater_] You left this in my car.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank you.  Uh, Jack, this is Daphne, my girlfriend.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_eyes him appraisingly_] Oh, you're a fine-looking one, aren't  you?

speaker: Jack
text: Oh, I don't know.

speaker: Daphne
text: Modest, that's good.  I don't see a wedding ring, you single?

speaker: Jack
text: Yes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Looking?

speaker: Jack
text: Sure.

speaker: Daphne
text: For a woman?

speaker: Jack
text: Right.

speaker: Daphne
text: Employed?

speaker: Jack
text: A surgeon.

speaker: Daphne
text: Mmm, impressive.

speaker: Jack
text: Thanks.

speaker: Niles
text: OK!  Well, uh, it's good to see you again, Jack,  thanks, goodbye.

speaker: Niles
text: What's happening?  I think I'm having some kind of stroke.

speaker: Daphne
text: Roz is lonely, so I got to try and set her up with someone.

speaker: Niles
text: Ohhhh, maybe Jack?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, there's a thought!

speaker: Niles
text: OK, I get it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Here we are.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Freddie.

speaker: Freddie
text: Hi, Uncle Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, would you give us a moment?

speaker: Daphne
text: Sure.

speaker: Niles
text: Freddie, about what you just saw - I know you've always had  special feelings for Daphne, and there's something I need to  tell you.

speaker: Freddie
text: I already know about you guys.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.  Uh, and you're OK with that?

speaker: Freddie
text: I liked her when I was a little kid.  I'm over it now.  I mean, she's like a hundred.

speaker: Niles
text: She most certainly is not. [_Nyah Nyah!_] It just burns you up  that I got her-

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  Why don't you get us both some sherry? [_he does_] Well,  Freddie, you know, I've made some wonderful plans for our time  together.  Uh, I've already chosen the book we're going to  read.  I'll give you a hint: published in 1854, this paean  to self-sufficiency was known as the "cornerstone of the  transcendental movement."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, Niles, I'll let you get the next one.  Freddie, any  thoughts?

speaker: Freddie
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: It's "Walden" by Henry David Thoreau.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course it is!  It is life near the bone, where it is  sweetest!  Should be the source of much lively discussion,  wouldn't you say?

speaker: Freddie
text: [_gets up and goes to the hall_] I don't know.  Why don't you  just talk about it with Uncle Niles?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles?  Well, uh, yes, if that's what you'd like.  We'll  discuss it together.

speaker: Niles
text: "As the engine whistles, let it whistle till it is hoarse for  its pain!"

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, shut up, Niles.  _FADE TO:    Scene Three - Apartment  Martin is reading the newspaper in his Armchair.  Frasier and Frederick  come in._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, how was the computer expo?

speaker: Freddie
text: OK. [_tosses his coat to Frasier_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Say, Freddie, why don't you tell Grandpa about the new virtual  reality-

speaker: Frasier
text: And he's gone.

speaker: Martin
text: You guys have fun?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yeah.  It was a blast, he spent the entire time trying to  ditch me.  You know, I only get to see Freddie a few times a  year, and usually we make the most of it.  Now all he wants to  do is play that damn computer game!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know, Fras, he's not much different than you were  at that age.  Except instead of video screens and electronics,  you always had your head in books.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's entirely different, Dad-

speaker: Martin
text: No, it isn't.  We couldn't get you to do anything.  You know,  I remember when you read that "Walden" book.  It was on the  family camping trip.

speaker: Frasier
text: So?  What better time to read about nature?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, that's just it.  While you were in the cabin reading  about it, we were outside enjoying it.  You'd rather read  about something than experience it firsthand.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, my mentor remarked on that very thing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Freddie? [_pulls off his headphones_] Freddie, I've made a  decision.  We are going to the woods.

speaker: Freddie
text: What for?

speaker: Frasier
text: We are going camping.  It'll be good for the both of us.

speaker: Freddie
text: But I don't want to.

speaker: Frasier
text: Too bad!  It'll be fun!  Fathers and sons should do fun things  together!

speaker: Freddie
text: You and Grandpa don't do fun things together.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, leave me out of it.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's why he's coming along as well!  There will be no TV,  there will be no electronics, there will be no distractions!  Just three generations of Cranes cooking over a fire and  sleeping under the stars!  We leave at daybreak!

speaker: Martin
text: Good work, Freddie!    _END OF ACT ONE    ACT TWO    Scene Four - Cabin  Frasier, Martin, and Frederick carry their bags into the rustic cabin._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, what an idyllic spot!  I'm already beginning to feel like  Thoreau.

speaker: Freddie
text: We can't sleep here, this place bites.

speaker: Frasier
text: It does not bite.  "It is shelter, as good as the best, and  sufficient for its coarser and simpler wants."

speaker: Freddie
text: That you talking, or that guy from "Where's Walden?"

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughs_] Good one, Freddie.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes. [_takes out two notebooks_] You know, the two of you may  want to immortalize this good-natured reality in these journals  that I bought for you.

speaker: Martin
text: Well thanks, but I don't know what to write.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Dad, you simply write down your experiences.

speaker: Freddie
text: I have to go to the bathroom.

speaker: Frasier
text: Freddie, I... I don't see a bathroom.

speaker: Martin
text: You're surrounded by fifty thousand acres of it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  Oh, how quaintly rustic!  Yes, Frederick, just pick a  tree and make it your own!

speaker: Frasier
text: So Dad, I thought we might do an activity later.

speaker: Martin
text: What kind of activity?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I don't know.  Maybe press some leaves, or-or whittle  a bird call and see if we can lure some finches to our sill.

speaker: Martin
text: Take it easy now, we want to save something for tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, could you please be a little more supportive?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'd like to, but I tried to get you to come camping  a million times, and you had to wait until the playoffs  were on!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you can watch the playoffs all year!

speaker: Freddie
text: The kids at the next campsite have got a rope swing.  Can I go  over?

speaker: Martin
text: Don't see why not.

speaker: Freddie
text: Thanks. [_leaves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: What the hell was that?

speaker: Martin
text: It's just a rope swing.  Wait'll he sees us drying leaves in  the sun, he'll come running.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I'm just about fed up with your sarcasm.  I'm trying  to do some father-son bonding here, so will you just butt out?!

speaker: Martin
text: [_opens his journal_] You know what?  I just thought of something  to write in this thing!   **WAS THERE A DOCTOR IN THE HOUSE?**    _Scene Five - Apartment  Roz, dressed for an evening out, comes out of the hall with Daphne.  Niles is waiting._

speaker: Roz
text: This is a bad idea.  My hair's flat.  Never have a good date  when my hair is flat.  If it's flat after, that's a good date.

speaker: Niles
text: Your hair is not flat, Roz.  It's delightfully frizzy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello.

speaker: Jack
text: Hi.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Jack, come in.  You remember Daphne, and this is Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: [_overcome_] Hi, Jack.

speaker: Jack
text: Hi.

speaker: Niles
text: So, uh, where are you two going for dinner?

speaker: Jack
text: I thought we'd try the Pergalu.  They have a garden patio.  Unless you'd rather eat inside, I don't want you to get cold.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, don't you worry about that.

speaker: Daphne
text: Come on, Roz.  I have a couple of wraps, you can borrow one.

speaker: Niles
text: What do you think?

speaker: Jack
text: She's pretty. [_takes out his cell phone_] You know, I should  check my service before we go.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, OK.  Can I pour you some wine?

speaker: Jack
text: Sure. [_into phone_] It's Dr. Belcher.  Really?  Well, isn't Dr.  Unger on call?  I'm kind of busy right now.  All right, I'm on  my way. [_hangs up_] There's an emergency with one of my post-op  patients.  Please tell Roz I'm really sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course.

speaker: Jack
text: Thanks, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, good luck.

speaker: Daphne
text: We need a man's opinion: the velvet trim or the multi-colored?  [_sees_] Where's Jack?

speaker: Niles
text: He left.

speaker: Roz
text: He left?!

speaker: Niles
text: It was an emergency.

speaker: Roz
text: What kind of an emergency?  Like he-saw-me-and-he-thought-I-  was-a-dog emergency?!

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, no, he said you were pretty.

speaker: Roz
text: That's it?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, he flew out of here as soon as you left the room.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh God, he was just trying to get out of this date!  I've been  dumped!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'm sure you weren't dumped!  He was paged, right, Niles?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh yeah, the whole fake page routine!

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, no, not even, he actually called in.

speaker: Roz
text: [_rock bottom_] I should go.

speaker: Niles
text: [_shows her to the door_] We understand, you want to be alone.

speaker: Daphne
text: No Roz, I won't hear of it, you'll stay right here with us!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I don't want to be a pain.  You guys had a big evening  planned.

speaker: Niles
text: [_keeps her moving_] Roz, you are so considerate.

speaker: Daphne
text: We can have an evening any old time.  You'll stay for dinner.

speaker: Roz
text: All right.

speaker: Niles
text: [_disappointed, takes her wrap_] Allow me.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, what are we having, �cause I don't like fish.    _Daphne turns around, gropes for something to say... and gives up.    FADE TO:    Scene Six - Cabin  Night has fallen.  Frasier and Martin are sitting at the table with  two plates.  Frederick comes in with two other boys and a girl his  age (Melody)._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Freddie, there you are!  Thank goodness.

speaker: Freddie
text: Can I have dinner with these guys?  They're having Sloppy  Joe's.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, but Frederick is going to be having dinner with his  family this evening.

speaker: Freddie
text: Come on, Dad!

speaker: Melody
text: It's OK.  Come by later, we're making s'mores.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, we'll see.  All right, now off you go, young people.  [_they leave_] Just sit down, Frederick, and eat your meal.

speaker: Martin
text: Have a good time?

speaker: Freddie
text: I guess.

speaker: Frasier
text: What'd you do?

speaker: Freddie
text: We played some Frisbee.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.

speaker: Freddie
text: It sucked with all those trees in the way.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, perhaps one day civilization will cut down all those  trees, and pave over this grand wilderness, then you and your  friends can play Frisbee without constraint, how would that be?

speaker: Freddie
text: I don't know. [_eats a bite_] I'm done, can I go now?

speaker: Frasier
text: No!

speaker: Freddie
text: Why not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Because this is your first camping trip, and we're gonna enjoy  it together!

speaker: Freddie
text: This isn't my first camping trip.

speaker: Frasier
text: You never told me that.

speaker: Freddie
text: I don't tell you a lot of things.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh ... I see.  Well, you may go. [_Frederick leaves_] So, he's  been camping before.  Instead of this being something special  between us, it's just another thing I've missed out on.  This  trip was a bust from the get-go.  We leave at daybreak!

speaker: Martin
text: What's with you and daybreak? [_gets up_] I'm gonna see if those  kids have a generous grandpa with a six-pack.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sit!    _Martin sits back down.  Glaring at Frasier, he opens his journal again.    FADE TO:_  **WHY DOES HIS BREATH SMELL LIKE MORTADELLA?**    _Scene Seven - Apartment  Daphne and Roz are sitting at the table before dinner._

speaker: Daphne
text: I once dated a guy who was so grabby I jumped out of his car  while it was still moving.

speaker: Roz
text: Did I ever tell you about this jerk named Nick?

speaker: Daphne
text: I dated a Nick!

speaker: Daphne
text: My Nick had a silent "g" at the beginning of his name.  He was Vietnamese.

speaker: Niles
text: I wonder who this could be?  _He opens the door to another man, as tall as Jack but rather dim-  looking._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh!  What an incredible surprise, it's Hans!  Hans, come in.  Roz, Daphne, this is Hans.  He's a doctor from my building.

speaker: Roz
text: Nice to meet you.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_suspicious_] Hello, Hans.  What brings you by?

speaker: Hans
text: [_obviously reciting lines_] I'm a friend of Frasier.  Uh, I was  downstairs, so I thought I'd pop by, see if he was here.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well he's not.

speaker: Niles
text: But still, you could stay for a drink.  Why don't you come  here, sit next to Roz?

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles, help me fix those drinks, will you?

speaker: Niles
text: [_evening's back on track!_] Yes, dear.

speaker: Daphne
text: Doctor, my eye!  That's Ted, the moron from the deli.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you sure?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, stop it!  You invited him over here for Roz.  Well, she's  in no mood to be trifled with, and neither am I.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I was trying to help.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well if you want to help, get rid of him.

speaker: Niles
text: [_one last try_] Love you.  _She turns away from his kiss, making her resolve clear.  He goes back  out as Roz comes in._

speaker: Roz
text: Can you believe this, Daphne?

speaker: Daphne
text: Roz, I am so sorry.  This evening's been a disaster.

speaker: Roz
text: No, I mean things are looking up!  Hans and I are really  hitting it off.  Do you have any mints in here?

speaker: Daphne
text: Uh, try the cupboards.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks.  I have a really good feeling about Hans.  He's very funny - he just told me he was Chief Doctor  of Brainiatrics! [_laughs_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Where did he go?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, I gave him the boot, he's gone.

speaker: Roz
text: [_coming out_] Who's gone?!

speaker: Niles
text: He had an emergency.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, you have got to be kidding me!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Roz-

speaker: Roz
text: I thought this one liked me!  Man, I've driven away  two doctors in one night!

speaker: Niles
text: No, uh, Hans is just the-the meat slicer from the deli.

speaker: Roz
text: And that's supposed to make me feel better?  Oh God, I just  want to put this whole night behind me!

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't blame you one bit.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sure it'll all look better in the morning.

speaker: Roz
text: I sure hope so.  You two have listened to enough of my  problems for one night.    _Niles brings her purse from the coat rack, but she flops down onto  the couch and turns on the TV._

speaker: Roz
text: Oh look, "Titanic" just started.    _As Daphne sits next to Roz, Niles looks fit to cry.    FADE TO:    Scene Eight - Cabin  Frasier is lying on the floor in his sleeping bag next to the fire.  Martin sits over him in a chair._

speaker: Martin
text: When you hear that scratching at your window late at night,  remember that young couple ... [_thrusts out his hand, with  a fork sticking out of the sleeve_] and Fork Hand!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on!  That's scary stuff.  I told that to Duke  last summer, and he wet his sleeping bag.

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait a minute.  Isn't this Duke's sleeping bag?!

speaker: Martin
text: _Now_ you're scared!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh gosh, Dad, I'm sorry I snapped at you earlier.  You know,  I guess I was just hoping this trip might give me and Frederick  some sort of, I don't know, golden moment.  I guess I'm just  disappointed.

speaker: Martin
text: I know.  But you know, none of this would be happening if we  had a TV.  TV makes everyone get along.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, buddy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Fred.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'll just take a little walk.

speaker: Frasier
text: OK.  See you in a bit, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: All right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Frederick, we're gonna be leaving in the morning.

speaker: Freddie
text: But I don't want to go.

speaker: Frasier
text: No?  I thought you'd be dying to get back to your Game Boy.

speaker: Freddie
text: Well, yeah.  But I kind of made plans.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  With who?

speaker: Freddie
text: Nobody.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, then you don't have plans.  We leave at... nine-ish.

speaker: Freddie
text: OK, fine.  I have plans with Melody.

speaker: Frasier
text: The s'mores girl?

speaker: Freddie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's cute.

speaker: Freddie
text: She's a cheerleader.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ho-ho!  I remember a particular cheerleader from my youth:  Lorna.  She was a beautiful girl.  In fact, I was so  intimidated by her I-I could never even work up the courage  to approach her-

speaker: Freddie
text: Dad, I kissed her.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh...

speaker: Freddie
text: I know.  It was her first time.  It was my first time too.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see.

speaker: Freddie
text: Don't tell Mom about this, OK?  She'd ask all kinds of stupid  questions.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't worry, son.  It's just between you and me.

speaker: Freddie
text: You know, I think I'll write for a while before bed.

speaker: Freddie
text: Whoa!  Did you see the stuff that Grandpa wrote about you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Give me that! [_snatches it away_]
